resources.string:
Earth: Our home planet has a dense metal core,
a thick viscous rock mantle, and a thin crust. 
It's unique in the solar system for having humans
and liquid water on its surface.

Moon: At 3470 km in diameter, the Moon has the
longest moon-to-planet ratio. It's thought to
have formed when a small planet impacted
Earth at a grazing angle billions of years
ago. It's heavily crated, and has huge
flood plains on it called mania.

Jupiter: A gas giant, it's the largest planet in
our solar system. It has a dynamic
atmosphere, including belts, zones,
and a gigantic red spot created by a
persistent hurricane. Its interior is mostly
metallic hydrogen, and it has the fastest spin of all planets.

Mercury: Orbiting the sun in just 89 days, it also has
the most elliptical orbit of any planet. 
It spins very slowly, once every 2/3
of its orbital period. Despite its
 surface reaching a blistering 430C,
it still has water ice in permanently
shadowed crates near its poles
where the temperature stays below -170C

Sun: Our star is 2 octillion tons of hot hydrogen gas
emitting 400 septillion of energy every 
second. The hottest part of the sun is its 15
million C core, when it's been fusing hydrogen into helium for the past 4.6 billion years.
Despite that it's only midlife aged!

Mars: Its iconic red color comes from its rusty
rocks and dust. In the past Mars was once 
very wet, with oceans, a thick atmosphere,
and a warmer climate.
But its lack of a magnetic field meant no protection from
the solar wind, which eroded its atmosphere away.

Venus: The planet with the hottest surface temperature, at 460C it\'s hot enough to melt lead. Its air is almost entirely composed of carbon dioxide, with a thick layer of sulphuric clouds. Its rotational axis is flipped upside-down, which means the planet spins backwards.

Europa: Possessing a water ocean under its icy crust, some scientists have theorized it may be capable of supporting life. These lifeforms might be similar to those on Earth that live next to thermal vents.
Saturn: A gas giant with a broad set of rings. It has a hexagonal cloud pattern on its north pole. It is the least dense of all the planets, even less than water!
Titan: Larger than Mercury, it\'s the only moon that has a dense atmosphere. It has methane cycle that is similar to Earth\'s water cycle, including rain and other weather events.
Uranus: An ice giant with a small rocky core and a thick mantle of ammonia, water and methane. It has thirteen distinct rings.
Neptune: An ice giant, with a similar composition to Uranus. It\'s the most dense gas giant planet and the only planet found by mathematical prediction rather than by empirical observation.

Pluto: Discovered in 1930 and categorized as a planet until 2006 when it was re-categorized as a minor planet. Similar large icy bodies have been found beyond neptune, including Eris, Makemake, and Haumea.
